Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 12, 13, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations
Application_Facts: The Band Council stopped holding membership meetings, added ineligible members, and ignored appeals. The Minister dismissed an election appeal without verifying voter list validity or ensuring procedural fairness.
Procedural_Issue: Dismissal of election appeal without procedural fairness
Jurisdictional_Issue: Band Council acted outside its jurisdiction
Outcome: Court ruled in favor of the applicant, ordering the Band Council to revise the membership list and declaring the Minister's actions unreasonable.
Remedy_Sought: Declaration of unreasonableness of Minister's actions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory compliance under the Indian Act and related regulations
Decision_Rationale: Band Council breached rule of law by acting outside jurisdiction; Minister's decision lacked justification and procedural fairness.

Legal_Provision: Section 12, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to investigate credible allegations of electoral misconduct
Governing_Law: Sections 12, 14 of the Indian Band Election Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: focused narrowly on direct exchange of alcohol for votes
Decision_Outcome: dismissed appeal due to insufficient evidence under incorrect standard
Burden_of_Proof: appearance of wrongdoing required, but higher standard applied
Legal_Rule: proof of appearance of wrongdoing suffices
Key_Evidence_Considered: investigator's report showing appearances of misconduct

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession and supplying of alcohol on a dry reserve
Governing_Law: s.14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: evidence of alcohol supply near election ignored due to lack of direct confirmation
Burden_of_Proof: appearance of wrongdoing standard not applied
Legal_Rule: appearance of wrongdoing sufficient under s.14

Crimes.Crime_Name: Contravention of Indian Band Election Regulations
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Sections 12, 14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Grounds_for_Claim: corrupt practices including vote-buying and voter influence
Jurisdiction: First Nation elections under federal regulations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Corrupt practices in connection with an election
Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 12, 14 of Indian Band Election Regulations
Application_Facts: alleged use of alcohol to influence voters
Evidentiary_Deficiency: requirement for actual proof instead of appearance
Legal_Standard_Applied: incorrectly required proof of actual wrongdoing
Decision_Rationale: failure to apply statutory standard under s.14

Legal_Issue: Whether the Department of Agriculture violated the plaintiff's legitimate expectation of permanent employment
Governing_Law: Principles of administrative law, legitimate expectation doctrine
Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff's service duration, promise by unauthorized superior, departmental reorganization records
Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff to establish a legitimate expectation and violation thereof
Credibility_Factor: Promise made by unauthorized superior, lack of continuous five-year service
Legal_Rule: Legitimate expectation arises from a promise by a public authority or consistent practice; ensures procedural fairness but does not create substantive rights
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and legality under administrative law
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-renewal of contract despite internal policy suggesting permanent status after five years
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim failed; no substantive right to permanent status
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration of employment, nature of promise, administrative policy, reorganization impact
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, doctrine of legitimate expectation
Defendant_Response: Policy was administrative and not legally binding; plaintiff did not meet continuity requirement; lawful prioritization of permanent employees during cuts
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, employment records, internal communications
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review seeking recognition of permanent status

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness by failing to disclose RCMP report and denying applicants a chance to respond
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Minister relied on RCMP investigation report instead of appointed investigator's report
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Ministerial Declaration and Order in Council set aside
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate unfairness, met due to lack of disclosure
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: RCMP report used without verification or opportunity for rebuttal
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness required under Indian Act and Regulations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of disclosure and opportunity to respond
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Indian Act, election appeals, Ministerial discretion
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Not provided â€“ applicants were not informed or given chance to respond
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, matter returned for proper procedures
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections of the Indian Act and associated Regulations governing election disputes
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada (INAC)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness by failing to disclose RCMP report and denying applicants an opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Minister relied on RCMP report without sharing with applicants
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Ministerial Declaration and Order in Council invalidated
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to show procedural unfairness, successfully demonstrated
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Use of undisclosed RCMP findings affecting rights and reputations
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness required in administrative decisions under Indian Act
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Non-disclosure of evidence and denial of right to respond
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles, Indian Act provisions on elections
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicants denied opportunity to address allegations
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and setting aside of Ministerâ€™s decision
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, remanded to Minister for reconsideration with fair process
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Relevant sections of Indian Act regarding electoral disputes and Ministerial authority
Crimes.Authority: Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness due to non-disclosure of RCMP report and lack of response opportunity
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Reliance on RCMP report over appointed investigator; no access given to applicants
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Ministerial Declaration and Order in Council invalidated
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicants showed breach of natural justice
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Critical reliance on confidential RCMP findings without transparency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Duty of fairness includes disclosure and right to be heard
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to disclose investigative findings and deny response
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No opportunity provided for applicants to refute allegations
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quashing of Ministerâ€™s declaration and order
Crimes.Outcome: Decisions set aside, matter referred back for proper procedure
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions of Indian Act concerning band council elections and appeals

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged vote-buying during Band Council election
Crimes.Governing_Law: Indian Act and associated electoral rules
Crimes.Application_Facts: Election appeal led to RCMP investigation and Ministerial action based on undisclosed report
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Individuals affected by declaration of office vacancies
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Minister failed to disclose report or allow response
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Ministerâ€™s authority under Indian Act vs. procedural fairness obligations
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure and inability to challenge evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RCMP report accepted without applicant input or verification
Crimes.Outcome: Case remanded for reconsideration with adherence to procedural fairness
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Ministerial Declaration and Order in Council
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Setting aside of decisions and return to Minister for proper process
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Use of evidence without disclosure violates natural justice
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Minister of Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminal charge under section 264.1(1)(a) of the Criminal Code
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of accepted Band custom
Legal_Rule: Removal must be authorized by Code or accepted Band custom
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of Code provision for removal
Policy limits removal to Portfolio only

Dispute_Type: Administrative law dispute over statutory interpretation and procedural compliance
Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister breached s. 47.1 of the Canadian Wheat Board Act by failing to consult and obtain producer consent before introducing Bill C-18
Governing_Law: Section 47.1 of the Canadian Wheat Board Act
Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of legislative intent, text of s. 47.1, and Ministerâ€™s actions in introducing Bill C-18 without consultation or vote
Decision_Outcome: Declarations granted that the Minister breached s. 47.1
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants (CWB and producers) to demonstrate statutory breach; met
Credibility_Factor: Ministerâ€™s interpretation of s. 47.1 deemed unreasonable by court
Legal_Rule: Section 47.1 requires consultation with CWB and producer consent via vote before introducing legislation that alters marketing mandate or structure
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to consult, failure to obtain producer consent, violation of procedural requirements under statute
Key_Evidence_Considered: Text of s. 47.1, legislative history, absence of consultation records, nature of changes in Bill C-18
Legal_Framework: Statutory interpretation principles, rule of law, administrative law procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Minister argued s. 47.1 applies only to grain inclusion/exclusion, not repeal of the Act
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (legislation, official records), legal argument
Remedy_Requested: Declarations of breach and failure to meet legitimate expectations
Outcome: Declarations granted; Minister found in breach of statutory duty

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the dismissal of Mr. Hudson's election appeal based on reasonable findings?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Significant evidence about irregularities in distribution of goods and money before the election was ignored; spending patterns were misinterpreted.
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to show corrupt practices occurred
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Investigator's report lacked thoroughness and ignored circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Court reviews decisions for reasonableness, considering evidence and procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegations of corrupt practices including vote-buying
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Errors in analysis rendered decision unreasonable
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Distribution of goods and money pre-election, spending patterns
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Judicial review under administrative law principles
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; dismissal set aside
Crimes.Authority: Minister responsible for elections under federal regulations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the dismissal of Hudson's election appeal based on reasonable findings?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient direct evidence found, but court identified errors in analysis of spending and procedural irregularities
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Dismissal overturned due to analytical errors
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Appellant must prove fraudulent practices by credible evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Investigation failed to properly assess circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Minister must investigate appeals and determine if corrupt practices occurred
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Decision dismissed due to flawed investigation
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Spending patterns, timing of distributions, procedural deviations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal electoral oversight for First Nations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denial or lack of admission noted
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the decision dismissing Mr. Hudson's appeal reasonable given evidence of misuse of public funds?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence of SNP program goods distribution pre-election ignored; lack of transparency and criteria
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Appellant must demonstrate misuse for electoral benefit
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Investigator misconstrued or overlooked key financial data
Crimes.Legal_Rule: If corrupt practice appears, Minister must report accordingly
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Use of public resources (SNP program) for electoral advantage
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Distribution records under SNP program, timing relative to election
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No adequate justification provided for distribution practices
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Financial records, program logs, witness accounts
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; no remittal due to new election
Crimes.Authority: Investigative officer (Mr. Dyck, Ms. Kustra), Minister

Crimes.Application_Facts: Allegations that Chief Stevenson engaged in vote-buying through goods distribution
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied misuse of authority and resources to influence voters
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider circumstantial evidence in investigation
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal jurisdiction over First Nation elections
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Distribution records, spending patterns, timing of benefits
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of direct evidence but strong circumstantial indicators ignored
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Investigator underestimated significance of indirect evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted; original decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial intervention to correct unreasonable decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Investigation failed to properly analyze available evidence
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Minister of Indigenous Services, appointed investigators

Application_Facts: Applicant lacked sufficient physical presence in Canada but maintained family and business ties
Residency_Compliance: Insufficient accumulation of 1095 days of residence over four years
Procedural_Issue: Failure of the citizenship judge to specify which residency test was applied (quantitative, qualitative, or centralized mode of living)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of clear reasoning on how residency requirement was satisfied
Outcome: Appeal granted; application remitted for re-determination by a different judge
Relief_Sought: Review of citizenship approval based on unclear residency assessment
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of residency compliance with proper reasoning
Decision_Rationale: Decision was unreasonable due to lack of clarity and transparency in applying residency tests

Application_Facts: Male applicant appointed as a land surveyor in Haiti; received threats due to political connections; claimed persecution based on this role
Procedural_Issue: Tribunal's failure to properly assess individualized risk; decision found unreasonable on judicial review
Evidence_Used: Threats linked to appointment as land surveyor; political ties; personal targeting evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal overlooked specific evidence of personal targeting
Decision_Outcome: Tribunal initially denied protection, finding only generalized risk
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a person in need of protection under IRPA
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a differently constituted tribunal
Decision_Rationale: Tribunal erred by treating the risk as generalized despite evidence of personal targeting related to political circumstances
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB); Federal Court on review

Violation_Type: Failure to meet burden of proof for refugee status
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 96-98
Governing_Law: 1951 Refugee Convention, Canadian Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant is an Ahmadi Muslim who faced harassment in home country; continued religious practice and studies; incidents deemed isolated by Refugee Division
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Evidence_Used: Incidents of harassment due to Ahmadi faith
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of systematic evidence showing persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Subjective fear acknowledged, but not objectively justified
Outcome: Application dismissed; applicant remains ineligible for refugee status
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Subjective fear + objectively justified risk of persecution based on Convention grounds
Decision_Rationale: Incidents were isolated and did not amount to systematic or serious discrimination constituting persecution
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division, Immigration and Refugee Board; Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Violation_Type: Immigration violation due to remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa, established herself in Canada, sent money home, has children in Canada
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary resident who became out of status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Exemption sought from requirement to apply for permanent residency from outside Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; establishment found admirable
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Application for humanitarian and compassionate grounds refused
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from outside application requirement based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness of officerâ€™s assessment under H&C provisions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Establishment was admirable but result of voluntary actions; no disproportionate hardship; best interests of children considered but not outweighing immigration compliance

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation and humanitarian relief under immigration law
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of officerâ€™s refusal of humanitarian and compassionate grounds for permanent residence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of applicant's establishment, family ties, and hardship upon removal
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unusual or undeserved hardship
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 25 allows exemption based on H&C grounds, including best interests of children
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship if deported, family ties in Canada, best interests of children
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate provisions under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Immigration Officer assessed factors and found no basis for exemption
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Officer and Federal Court (on review)

Governing_Law: UN Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Grygorian faced anti-Semitism but could claim Russian or Israeli citizenship; Board found her eligible for these nationalities
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application heard by Federal Court, Trial Division
Evidence_Used: Evidence of potential claims to Russian and Israeli citizenship
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refugee status denial
Remedy_Sought: Intervention by Federal Court to overturn Board decision
Decision_Rationale: Grygorian had access to protection through potential nationality in Russia or Israel, making her ineligible for refugee status under the Convention

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in applying Articles 1E and 1F(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; findings accepted as reasonable
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Rights akin to nationality in Mexico
Serious nonpolitical crime in the U.S.
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged errors in law and fact findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation of exclusion clauses under the Refugee Convention

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in applying Articles 1E and 1F(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board's findings deemed reasonable
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee status based on fear of persecution

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to maintain valid immigration status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to renew Mexican immigration documents
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timing and validity of refugee claim
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Eligibility for refugee protection in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; exclusion based on legal criteria
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant had effective nationality-like rights and committed a serious crime

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether bribery for travel documents triggers exclusion under Articles 1E and 1F(b)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Pattern of fraudulent conduct affecting credibility
Evidence_Type: History of bribing for Iranian passports
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution in home country
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of factual and legal conclusions
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Exclusion for serious nonpolitical crimes and de facto nationality

Crimes.Application_Facts: Permanent resident in Mexico who did not renew status
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timeliness and admissibility of refugee claim
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Refugee eligibility despite prior stable status
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not pivotal; exclusion based on objective criteria
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Enjoyed rights akin to nationality and committed serious crime

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether failure to maintain status and criminal history justify exclusion
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Findings accepted as reasonable
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection due to fear of persecution
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Loss of status due to non-renewal
Crimes.Application_Error: Alleged errors in interpretation of exclusion clauses
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior lawful status and criminal conduct
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of expired or invalid documents in application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious nonpolitical crime outside the country of refuge
Crimes.Application_Facts: Guilty plea in the U.S. for attempted sexual battery
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Interaction between criminal history and refugee eligibility
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether crime disqualifies applicant regardless of persecution risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Secondary to legal exclusion
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: No balancing of crime severity and persecution risk
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Serious nonpolitical crime committed outside country of habitual residence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status due to criminal conduct
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether bribery constitutes a serious nonpolitical crime under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Board relied on conviction and pattern of misconduct
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show entitlement to protection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Pattern of corrupt behavior affects trustworthiness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) excludes those with serious nonpolitical crimes
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution in country of origin
Key_Evidence_Considered: Guilty plea for attempted sexual battery
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law and domestic immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Sought refugee protection despite criminal history

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 200 days due to caring for her ill mother and business trips
Residency_Compliance: Failed to accumulate 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Procedural_Issue: Appeal to the Federal Court after denial by Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Records of absences, humanitarian reasons for travel
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient evidence to meet physical presence test despite compelling reasons
Legal_Standard_Applied: 1095-day physical presence requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably applied the physical presence test within their discretion; humanitarian reasons did not override statutory requirement

Violation_Type: Failure to meet definition of Convention refugee
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration Act - Definition of Convention refugee
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, IRPA, s. 96-98
Application_Facts: Applicant born in Russia, resided in Latvia, claimed statelessness and persecution; court found she was entitled to Russian citizenship through a simple formality (passport stamp); no evidence of persecution in Russia
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking refugee status in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Applicant residing in Latvia, outside country of nationality (Russia)
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Board's decision
Evidence_Used: Evidence regarding eligibility for Russian citizenship, lack of proof of persecution in Russia
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of actual persecution in Russia
Claim of statelessness not substantiated due to entitlement to Russian citizenship
Credibility_Assessment: Court found claim of statelessness unconvincing due to available access to Russian citizenship
Relief_Sought: Stay in Canada under protected status
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Boardâ€™s negative determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the 1951 Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Applicant has effective nationality (Russia), can avail herself of state protection, and failed to demonstrate a well-founded fear of persecution

Violation_Type: Failure to meet burden of proof for refugee status
Lack of nexus to Convention grounds
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96 and 97
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution by uncle and NDC officials in Ghana after leaving political party; reported attack to police but could not identify assailants; cited political opinion as basis for fear
Claimant_Status: Applicant for refugee protection in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable â€“ claimant was outside country of nationality seeking protection
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on Ghana's police reforms
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence that state was unable or unwilling to protect
No identification of attackers limited police response
Lack of evidence linking harm to Convention grounds
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant did not sufficiently demonstrate state protection failure or persecution nexus
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to rebut presumption of state protection; insufficient evidence of state inability or unwillingness to act; no established nexus between alleged harm and Convention grounds

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD's decision was patently unreasonable or involved an error of law
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 28(1)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 28(1) - Residency obligation of 730 days in 5 years
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to meet physical presence requirement
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Only 360 days of physical presence in Canada between 1997 and 2002
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Appeal before Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), followed by judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Compliance with IRPA s. 28(1) residency requirement
Crimes.Application_Factor: Time spent outside Canada without authorization under deemed presence rules
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with residency obligations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Angeles spent only 360 days in Canada from 1997 to 2002
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant â€“ failed to meet 730-day requirement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged procedural unfairness in IAD proceedings
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Angeles failed to provide sufficient evidence or documentation to support appeal
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD upheld removal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal, reinstatement of permanent resident status
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal error or patently unreasonable finding by IAD

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in use of extrinsic evidence
Key_Factor_in_Determination: No substantial wrong or miscarriage of justice
Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation via reliance on sister's removal order

Application_Facts: Applied for permanent residence on humanitarian grounds
Procedural_Issue: Use of extrinsic evidence without explicit notice
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds

Application_Facts: Mr. Acharige argued that the PRRA Officer erred in assessing his risk claims; he claimed risks in Sri Lanka due to political involvement and alleged murder ties.
Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal after judicial review application
Evidence_Used: PRRA assessment, RPD findings, applicant's submissions
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Arguments found speculative and unsupported by credible evidence
Credibility_Assessment: The RPD and PRRA Officer both concluded Mr. Acharige was not at risk in Sri Lanka; lack of credibility in risk claims
Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal pending resolution of risk claims
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-part test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue
Decision_Rationale: Court found arguments speculative and lacking credible evidence; prior decisions found no risk in Sri Lanka
Authority_Responsible: Federal Court (judicial review), PRRA Officer (administrative decision)

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee eligibility criteria
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), sections 96 and 97
Governing_Law: Canadian refugee law, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed racial and political persecution in Guyana; Board found crimes were economically motivated, not linked to race or political opinion
Residency_Compliance: N/A - claimant was outside country of origin seeking protection
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence on crime patterns in Guyana, PPP's political power, police conduct
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of racial or political motivation for harm
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant did not demonstrate personalized risk or persecution based on Convention grounds
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a Convention refugee or person in need of protection
Remedy_Sought: Overturn of IRB decision through judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution on Convention grounds: race, religion, nationality, political opinion, or membership in a particular social group
Decision_Rationale: Persecution was economically driven; state protection available through impartial police and functioning political system
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status based on fear of persecution in Ghana; cited risks due to past events and personal circumstances
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment conducted by Refugee Division; Federal Court reviewed for legal error
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, country condition reports on Ghana, human rights developments
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroboration for significant events mentioned by applicant
Credibility_Assessment: Testimony found implausible due to inconsistencies and omissions
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the 1951 Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Credibility doubts combined with improved country conditions in Ghana reduce risk of future persecution; findings supported by evidence
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division, Immigration and Refugee Board

Violation_Type: Failure to meet refugee protection criteria
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), principles of persecution under international law
Application_Facts: Mr. Usta fled Turkey due to alleged persecution for his religious beliefs and conscientious objection to military service
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with immigration status upon claim rejection
Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment, cumulative errors in application of law
Evidence_Used: Board's assessment of subjective and objective evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible, plausible, and objective evidence supporting persecution claim
Credibility_Assessment: Claim found not credible by the Board
Decision_Rationale: No evidence of discrimination or disproportionate punishment under Turkish law; claim lacked credibility and plausibility
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 101(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Governing_Law: Canadian jurisprudence on standard of review and procedural fairness
Application_Facts: Gavryushenko claimed fear of persecution in Russia due to political opposition to the Chechen war and threats from fascist groups; he passed through the U.S. without seeking asylum there
Residency_Compliance: Complied with Canadian entry requirements; applied for refugee status upon arrival
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged fabrication of persecution claims by the Refugee Division, despite noted candour
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide clear and unambiguous reasons for credibility findings
Evidence_Used: Circumstances of travel through the U.S.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Tribunal ignored relevant evidence submitted after arrival
Misinterpreted failure to claim asylum in the U.S.
Credibility_Assessment: Mixed: praised candour but ultimately found allegations fabricated without clear justification
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim initially rejected by Refugee Division
Outcome: Referred back for rehearing before a new panel
Relief_Sought: Quashing of the Refugee Divisionâ€™s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Decision_Rationale: The Federal Court found the Refugee Divisionâ€™s reasoning unclear and internally inconsistent, particularly regarding credibility, and failing to properly address key evidence
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Dhillon failed to provide sufficient economic or family ties to India, had no travel history, and most of his children lived in Canada.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to demonstrate intent to comply with authorized stay
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No interview conducted by Visa Officer
Evidence_Used: Lack of family ties in home country
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of intent to return to India
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Visa Officer found applicant's intent to leave Canada doubtful
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Applicant must prove they will leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant did not meet burden of proof; risk of overstaying assessed as high

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to demonstrate sufficient ties to home country
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer committed a reviewable error in rejecting the application
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA and Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant lacked proof of economic/family ties, income, and travel history
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate intent to return
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Most children reside in Canada; weak connections to India
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicant must prove they will leave Canada at end of authorized stay
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for factual findings; correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged reviewable error by Visa Officer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Absence of strong economic ties to India
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No obligation to conduct interview if application is insufficient

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Visa Officer made a reviewable error in assessing risk of overstaying
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s. 11(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations s. 179
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant perceived as high risk due to lack of ties to home country
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Concerns about potential overstaying due to insufficient home country ties
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Majority of children living in Canada; no strong economic base in India
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden on applicant to show intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Application_Factor: Lack of travel history, income proof, and familial/economic anchors in India

Prior_Criminality: Applicant's involvement in a robbery (charges later withdrawn)

Violation_Type: Security clearance denial based on past criminal incident
Application_Facts: Applicant was informed of the incident and given a chance to respond
Procedural_Issue: No right to a hearing; request for specific grounds deemed unnecessary

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (liberty rights)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Section 7; Crown Liability and Proceedings Act; Federal Court Act
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Application for interlocutory injunction or stay in Federal Court
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Plaintiff voluntarily joined training program; release was discretionary; grievance process incomplete; no evidence of contractual obligation to grant leave
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to show serious issue arising under Section 7
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not explicitly challenged; focus on legal entitlement rather than credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 7 protects liberty, but no positive obligation on Crown to grant discretionary release; injunctive relief against Crown is restricted
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Serious issue to be tried; appropriateness of injunctive relief
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of leave/voluntary release to pursue graduate studies
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Training agreement, request for leave, refusal by authorities, ongoing grievance procedure
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Charter rights vs. administrative discretion in military/service obligations
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No legal or contractual obligation to release plaintiff; proper procedures followed
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Injunction or stay to prevent enforcement of duty reporting
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Terms of service agreement under Medical Officer Training Plan
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, Section 7; Crown Liability and Proceedings Act, Section 22
Crimes.Application_Facts: Plaintiff sought leave to pursue further studies; request denied; failed to report for duty
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Ongoing grievance process; premature judicial intervention
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over Charter claims and injunctive relief against Crown
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Service agreement, request for leave, denial letter, grievance filing
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No proof of legal entitlement to release or breach of contract
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not central; decision based on legal interpretation
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Injunctive relief to prevent enforcement of duty reporting
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay or injunction based on alleged Charter violation
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue under Section 7 of the Charter
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Serious issue to be tried standard
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No legal or contractual right to release; voluntary commitment; grievance process not exhausted

Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence within the four years preceding the application; time spent studying abroad did not count toward residency
Evidence_Used: Record of days physically present in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required 1,095 days of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Decision_Rationale: The residency requirement ensures 'Canadianization'; absence from Canada for extended periods, including for study, does not fulfill the statutory obligation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose criminal conviction in immigration documents
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of the Board's exclusion analysis under Article 1F(b) of the Refugee Convention
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to disclose prior conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal conviction record, immigration application documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Prior fraud conviction not disclosed in immigration documents
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider low actual sentence and wide Canadian sentencing range
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Seriousness based on international norms and domestic sentencing practices
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Mitigating factors, actual sentence served (165 days)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Presumption of seriousness rebuttable by context
Crimes.Application_Factor: Maximum sentence in Canada (14 years) vs. actual sentence imposed
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remitted for redetermination by a different panel

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant convicted of fraud in Korea prior to seeking refugee status
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not applicable â€“ crime occurred pre-admission
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to conduct contextual assessment of crime seriousness
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Application of Canadian sentencing norms to foreign conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Foreign conviction record, Canadian equivalent sentencing provisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis of mitigating circumstances
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Undermined due to nondisclosure
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Presumption of seriousness if punishable by 10+ years in Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Need for contextual analysis despite presumptive seriousness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee protection based on seriousness of prior crime
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board reasonably applied Article 1F(b) exclusion
Crimes.Governing_Law: Article 1F(b), Refugee Convention; Canadian Criminal Code (fraud over $5,000)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Consideration of Korean conviction and Canadian sentencing equivalence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the state to prove seriousness for exclusion
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Non-disclosure affects credibility but does not automatically establish seriousness
Crimes.Legal_Rule: A crime with maximum 10+ year sentence is presumptively serious but rebuttable
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Error in failing to assess mitigating factors and low end of sentencing range
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Actual sentence (10 months, 165 days served), nature of fraud
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law and domestic analogues
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Foreign judgment, expert or legal comparison of sentencing
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 380(1)(a) of the Criminal Code (fraud over $5,000); Article 1F(b)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer breached procedural fairness by not allowing the applicant to respond to doubts about document authenticity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Employment letters deemed fabricated due to inconsistencies (e.g., similar fonts, ink-jet printing, duties copied from NOC codes)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of allegedly fabricated documents to meet work experience requirements under the Federal Skilled Worker class
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility in submitted documents rather than insufficiency
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness does not apply if concerns arise directly from regulatory requirements or lack of credibility
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience documentation for Federal Skilled Worker application

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation of work experience through fabricated employment letters
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided employment letters with content copied from NOC descriptions and poor-quality printing
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency under Federal Skilled Worker class
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in not allowing response to document concerns
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting claimed work experience
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Documents found to be fabricated based on inconsistencies and copying from NOC codes
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa application denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No procedural fairness breach as concerns were based on statutory credibility assessments

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with conditions of stay

Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: 'Keep the peace and be of good behaviour' under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: IAD erred by not considering all circumstances and misinterpreting 'good behaviour'

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to stop at a red light
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'good behaviour' condition in immigration context
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether traffic convictions constitute a breach of 'keep the peace and be of good behaviour'
Crimes.Governing_Law: Ontario Highway Traffic Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD found no breach; court found error
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On appellant to demonstrate reasonableness of IAD decision
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Compliance with provincial laws is required under 'good behaviour' condition
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: IAD misinterpreted legal standard and precedent
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration law requiring compliance with all statutes
Crimes.Outcome: Decision set aside, remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA relating to conditions of stay

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failing to surrender a driver's license
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Interpretation of 'good behaviour' under immigration law
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether conviction under Ontario Highway Traffic Act breaches 'be of good behaviour'
Crimes.Governing_Law: Ontario Highway Traffic Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for failure to surrender license
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD concluded no breach; challenged in review
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Any conviction under provincial law constitutes a breach unless trivial
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: IAD failed to recognize statutory breach

Crimes.Legal_Framework: Requirement to abide by all levels of law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Minor infractions not indicative of poor behaviour
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Condition to 'keep the peace and be of good behaviour'

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not disputed

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Controlled Drugs and Substances Act
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: IAD failed to consider humanitarian and compassionate factors
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: History of traffic offenses; potential for more serious conduct
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Potential link to broader criminal behavior

Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Failure to consider all circumstances and misinterpretation of 'good behaviour'
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Failure to analyze rehabilitation, family ties, hardship

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD erred in dismissing the applicants' refugee claims due to inadequate evidence of state protection and misinterpretation of IRPA

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Incidents occurred in conjunction with sexual assault and threats

Legal_Issue: Failure to adequately analyze claim of religious persecution

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Complaint of differential treatment in union representation
Decision_Outcome: Application allowed; decision overturned and remanded for redetermination
Credibility: Applicant provided arguments and evidence not adequately considered
Legal_Provision: Canadian Human Rights Act - Prohibited grounds of discrimination
State_Protection_Adequacy: Found inadequate due to failure to properly assess complaint

Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in law by improperly applying the residency test
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant's residential connection to Canada and other countries
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; Citizenship Judge's decision overturned
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to demonstrate eligibility under one of the residency tests
Legal_Rule: Three residency tests: strict count of days, quality of residence, or substantial connection; judge must apply chosen test correctly
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on legal interpretation
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of residency test by blending strict time calculation with substantial connection without proper analysis
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and nature of Applicant's presence in Canada, connections to other countries
Legal_Framework: Canadian citizenship law under the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of residence, travel records, personal testimony
Remedy_Requested: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge's decision and reassessment of citizenship application
Legal_Provision: Sections of the Citizenship Act relating to residency requirements

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer reasonably concluded the Applicant was a member of a terrorist organization
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Initial admission at port of entry, corroborating evidence, inconsistent denials
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the Officer to establish reasonable grounds for belief
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Inconsistent statements by the Applicant affected credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Membership requires more than casual involvement
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied to Officer's decision
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged membership in FMLN, a designated terrorist organization
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denied membership after initially admitting it
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral statements, documentary consistency, behavioral credibility
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review to overturn inadmissibility finding

Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant previously admitted membership, later denied

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to contradictions
Credibility_Factors: Lack of plausible explanation for change in story
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility and refusal of permanent residence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged misrepresentation regarding terrorist organization membership

Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not applicable â€“ issue centered on verbal/written misstatements, not forged documents

Legal_Issue: Was the Officer's decision to deny permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds procedurally fair and reasonable?
Evidence_Assessment: The Officer used extrinsic evidence about education and health services without disclosing it.
Decision_Outcome: The application for judicial review is granted, the decision is set aside, and the case is remitted for redetermination by a different officer.
Legal_Rule: The Officer must consider hardships, best interests of the child, and avoid reliance on extrinsic evidence without giving the applicant a chance to respond.
Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant claimed hardship upon return to her home country due to lack of support and potential threats.
Outcome_on_Merits: Insufficient analysis of the child's best interests; decision overturned.
Key_Evidence_Considered: Extrinsic evidence on education and health services, risks of abuse in home country
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, redetermination by a different officer
Outcome: Decision overturned, case sent back for reconsideration

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Board's decision on refugee status
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in applicant's testimony, unreliable documentation
Legal_Provision: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credible evidence supporting persecution claim
Application_Error: Insufficient credible evidence provided by applicant
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Evidence_Ignored: Some aspects related to registered church practices
Application_Factor: Credibility findings, evidence assessment, legal interpretation

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in determining that the applicants were not Convention refugees or persons in need of protection
Credibility_Assessment: Principal applicant's inconsistent statements undermined credibility
Evidence_Type: Credible evidence of state protection in Peru, reasonable Internal Flight Alternative (IFA) in Lima

Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to Board's decision
Legal_Standard: Burden on claimants to prove lack of state protection and absence of viable IFA
Application_Factor: Credibility, state protection, internal flight alternative

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 116 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in Canada beyond the authorized period of stay
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Reliance on undisclosed risk assessment documents
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Undisclosed risk assessment based on external sources
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure to applicants prior to decision
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision set aside
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of H&C application rejection
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of H&C application with procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Duty of fairness under Baker v. Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to provide applicants opportunity to respond to adverse information

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in use of undisclosed evidence
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Criminal Code
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of H&C application rejection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Risk assessment based on undocumented sources related to tax conviction
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: H&C application rejected; landing approval revoked

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Principles of procedural fairness from Baker v. Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Use of undisclosed evidence in decision-making
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Tax evasion conviction and associated risk assessment
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA sections 4(1)(a), 25(1); Baker duty of fairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Immigration Officer relied on internal risk assessment without disclosure

Crime_Name: Making false statements to obtain immigration benefits
Legal_Issue: Did the CRDD err in rejecting the applicant's claim based on credibility and fabrication of evidence?
Outcome: The CRDD's decision is set aside due to reviewable error, and the case is remanded for reconsideration.
Credibility_Assessment: The CRDD doubted the applicant's credibility without sufficient evidence and misinterpreted supporting documents.
Application_Error: Basing credibility solely on lack of documentation
Assessment_Standard: The CRDD must provide clear reasons for rejecting evidence and cannot base credibility solely on lack of documentation.
Legal_Standard: The CRDD must evaluate evidence fairly, considering all documentation and testimony.
Standard_of_Review: Judicial review analyzed the CRDD's decision, applying legal standards for evaluating evidence and credibility.
Document_Fraud: Fabrication of evidence regarding police actions

Legal_Issue: Was the CRDD's decision to reject the applicant's claim based on credible evidence and proper evaluation of facts?
Outcome: The CRDD's decision was flawed due to disregard for material evidence. The case is referred back for redetermination.
Credibility_Assessment: The CRDD doubted the applicant's credibility due to perceived inconsistencies in his evidence.
Basis_of_Claim: Family harassment due to brother's involvement in Sikh separatism
Application_Error: Dismissal of key testimonies and reports
Assessment_Standard: The CRDD must evaluate evidence fairly, considering all documentation and testimony. Inconsistencies must be supported by evidence.
Evidence_Ignored: Expert testimony on plausibility of abuse
Legal_Standard: The CRDD must evaluate evidence fairly, considering all documentation and testimony.
Standard_of_Review: Judicial review analyzed CRDD's credibility assessment and evidence evaluation, finding errors in dismissing key testimonies and reports.
Document_Fraud: Alleged fabrication of police actions and medical report

Crime_Name: Administrative Error in Visa Application Process
Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer correctly applied s. 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations in assessing Mr. Marr's educational credentials
Governing_Law: Section 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Outcome: The officer erred by failing to consider special circumstances under s. 78(4); decision set aside and application remitted for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Educational credential, duration of study, information on Scotlandâ€™s education system
Legal_Provision: s. 78(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient points awarded due to misapplication of regulations regarding educational credentials
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer failed to consider special circumstances such as shorter education system in Scotland
Decision_Maker: Visa officer, later reviewed by Federal Court
Application_Error: Incorrect point allocation (15 instead of 20) for educational credential
Evidence_Ignored: Potential relevance of Scotlandâ€™s shorter post-secondary education system
Application_Factor: Two-year post-secondary credential with 13 years of study (not meeting 14-year threshold)
Decision_Outcome: Application refused initially; decision quashed and remitted for re-evaluation
